docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A recent experience with health insurance illustrates the administrative costs noted in ''The Missing Rivalry in Health Care'' (Armchair M.B.A., Aug. 15). I was initially delighted when I received a letter from a cost-containment contractor for my insurance carrier stating that it was investigating whether a $4,450 charge for an M.R.I. was reasonable.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A recent experience with health insurance illustrates the administrative costs noted in ''The Missing Rivalry in Health Care'' (Armchair M.B.A., Aug. 15).    I was initially delighted when I received a letter from a cost-containment...

docs.lead_paragraph: A friend and I disagree about an investment he wants to make. It involves buying (at a discount) the life insurance of terminally ill individuals who want proceeds from their policies before their demise. My friend sees this as helping the ''victim'' receive funds now. I see it as making money from someone's death. You? Stanley Farb, Jeffersonville, Pa. Your friend would indeed profit from someone's death -- as do morticians, limousine drivers and florists. That in itself is not discreditable, assuming he does not hasten that death (by, for instance, running someone over with the limo or bludgeoning him with a bouquet). You might better see that insurance policy as akin to any asset a person sells to raise cash: a car, a savings bond, a record collection. If you buy it at a fair price -- that ambiguous but significant term -- you do no wrong.

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 9-5-04: THE ETHICIST

docs.abstract: Randy Cohen The Ethicist column responds to question about ethics of investing in life insurance of terminally ill individuals who want proceeds from their policies before they die; also answers question about ethics of telling parents about behavior of their teenage daughter; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: "A friend and I disagree about an investment he wants to make. It involves buying (at a discount) the life insurance of terminally ill individuals who want proceeds from their policies before their demise. ..."

docs.lead_paragraph: Ayana Teneile Wright, a daughter of Deborah Smith-Wright and Raymond Wright of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married last evening to Miguel Urskin Lambert, the son of Mary Joyce Lambert of the Bronx and Mathias Maxwell of Laborie, St. Lucia. The Rev. Walter A. Birkle, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Grace Church in the Bronx. Mrs. Lambert, 28, and Mr. Lambert, 26, graduated from Georgetown University, where they both won N.C.A.A. All-American track and field titles in the distance medley relay.
docs.snippet: Ayana Teneile Wright was married Saturday to Miguel Urskin Lambert at Our Lady of Grace Church in the Bronx.

docs.lead_paragraph: A day after President Bush heralded his efforts to help the elderly cope with increased medical expenses, federal officials announced the largest premium increase in dollars in the Medicare program's history, raising the monthly expense by $11.60 to $78.20. The increase, which amounts to 17 percent, results largely from increased payments to doctors and reflects rising medical expenses generally, officials said. The rise has nothing to do with a program that will start in 2006 to offer prescription drugs, for which beneficiaries must pay a separate premium.

headline.main: Citing Higher Costs, U.S. Plans Record Rise in Medicare Premium

docs.abstract: Federal officials announce largest premium increase in dollars in Medicare's history, raising monthly expense by 17 percent to $78.20; rise results largely from increased payments to doctors and is unrelated to prescription drug program, but increase immediately becomes grist for contentious presidential campaign; Medicare administrator Mark McClellan says about $1.75 of $11.60 increase comes from billions of dollars Medicare is paying insurers to encourage them to offer private plans; significant part of increased premium will go to bolster Medicare trust fund (L)
docs.snippet: The announcement of the 17 percent hike came a day after President Bush heralded efforts to help the elderly with medical costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: The pace of job creation picked up modestly in August and the unemployment rate edged down, the Labor Department said on Friday in a report that offered some political relief to the White House but only tepid signs of a rebound in employment. The nation added 144,000 jobs in August, twice as many as in July but just barely enough to keep pace with increases in the adult population. The unemployment rate declined to 5.4 percent from 5.5 percent in July, with new jobs being created in most sectors of the economy.

headline.main: 144,000 Jobs Were Added in August, a Bit of an Uptick

docs.abstract: Labor Department reports that jobless rate declined slightly to 5.4 percent in August, from 5.5 percent in July, with new jobs being created in most sectors of economy; reports increase of 144,000 jobs, twice as many as in July; economists say employment has grown more slowly since end of 2001 recession than during any previous recovery in last half century; graphs; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The Labor Department report offered some political relief to the White House but only tepid signs of a rebound in employment.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald, the brokerage firm that lost 658 employees in the Sept. 11 attack, has sued Saudi Arabia, charging that the kingdom ''provided funding and material support and substantial assistance'' to Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan this week, goes further than previous 9/11 damage suits in its accusations against the Saudi government and royal family. It singles out four Saudi officials, saying they organized and controlled a network of financial institutions and charities that aided Al Qaeda for at least seven years before 9/11.

headline.main: Saudi Arabia Is Sued by Firm That Lost 658 In Twin Towers

docs.abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald, brokerage firm that lost 658 employees in Sept 11 attack, sues Saudi Arabia, charging that kingdom provided funding and material support to Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden; seeks $7 billion, including $200 million in damages that were not covered by insurance; suit singles out Prince Nayef bin Abdel Aziz, Prince Sultan bin Abdel Aziz, Prince Salman bin Abdel Aziz and Prince Turki al-Faisal (M)
docs.snippet: Cantor Fitzgerald, a brokerage firm that lost 658 employees in the Sept. 11 attack, has sued Saudi Arabia, charging that the kingdom supported terrorism.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Kerry opened the final 60 days of the presidential campaign on Friday with a slashing indictment of President Bush's record on jobs and health care, saying he had misled the United States into war in Iraq and left a trail of broken promises and worsened problems at home. As his running mate and their wives swept across the electoral battlegrounds of Iowa, Michigan and Wisconsin, Mr. Kerry asked voters in this economically battered state to look past Mr. Bush's ''last-minute promises'' and focus on what he said were the facts: 1.7 million jobs lost since 2000, 1.4 million more people in 2003 without health insurance than the year before and 1.3 million more in poverty.

headline.main: Kerry Urges Voters to Look Past Bush's 'Last-Minute Promises'

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry, campaigning in Newark, Ohio, asks voters to look past Pres Bush's 'last-minute promises' and focus on numbers of jobs lost and people without health insurance; seizes on economic data showing only modest job growth; Kerry has returned to offensive after his character, voting history and patriotism were questioned by Republicans; even Kerry's comments on Iraq focus on economics of war and its potential impact on domestic priorities; photo (L)
docs.snippet: John Kerry opened the final 60 days of the campaign with an indictment of President Bush's record on jobs and health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 98 percent of hospitals in the United States are reporting quality-of-care data for treating heart attack, heart failure and pneumonia, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services said yesterday. The reporting of the information, which will be available to consumers online or by phone in early 2005, is voluntary, but hospitals that do not comply face lower reimbursement than other hospitals.

headline.main: Most Hospitals Are Posting Data on Care

docs.abstract: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services says more than 98 percent of hospitals in US are reporting quality-of-care data for treating heart attack, heart failure and pneumonia; reporting of information, which will be available to consumers online or by phone in early 2005, is voluntary, but hospitals that do not comply face lower reimbursement than other hospitals (S)
docs.snippet: More than 98 percent of hospitals in the United States are now reporting quality-of-care data for treating heart attack, heart failure and pneumonia, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid said yesterday

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID SERVICES

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's acceptance speech last night included assertions about his accomplishments and Senator John Kerry's past statements and voting patterns that were at best selective, and in some cases challenged by the historical record. Not surprisingly, they were also challenged by the Kerry campaign, which refuted some of Mr. Bush's accusations and pleaded guilty with an explanation to others.

headline.main: Comparing the President's Acceptance Speech and History
headline.kicker: THE REPUBLICANS: THE CONVENTION IN NEW YORK -- THE RECORD

docs.abstract: Article explains how several assertions in Pres Bush's acceptance speech are refuted by historical record and fact (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush's acceptance speech included assertionsthat were at best selective, and in some cases challenged by the historical record.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and ELISABETH BUMILLER

docs.lead_paragraph: The Walter Mondale Where's-the-Beef Award: George W. Bush, who told the conventioneers, ''Anyone who wants more details on my agenda can find them online.'' Ever the wonks, we followed the directions to georgewbush.com, seeking the details of the crowd-pleasing promise in his speech to ''lead a bipartisan effort to reform and simplify the federal tax code.'' Here's all we found: ''President Bush will work with Congress to make the tax code simpler for taxpayers, encourage saving and investment, and improve the economy's ability to create jobs and raise wages.'' Most overanalyzed gimmick: The round stage for President Bush's acceptance speech. Was it designed so he would look like a pitcher all alone on the mound, or a man of the people in the center of the hall? After the Democrats projected strength with a stage looking like a battleship, was Mr. Bush trying to soften his image by standing on a platform without any hard edges? With the spotlight on him, would he come off as Teddy Roosevelt, ''the man in the arena,'' or more like Thomas E. Dewey, derided as ''the little man on the wedding cake''?

headline.main: The Show Is Over. Now for the Awards.
headline.kicker: THE REPUBLICANS: THE CONVENTION IN NEW YORK -- POLITICAL POINTS

docs.abstract: Political Points column; list of humorous 'best-of awards' from Republican National Convention; drawings (M)
docs.snippet: The Walter Mondale Where's-the-Beef Award: George W. Bush, who told the conventioneers, "Anyone who wants more details on my agenda can find them online."
